instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> seems to be power cycling. I get bursts of the S3 and S0 rails. <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> cycles high-low. Can't find any shorts or heat on the board. <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> also seems to be cycling, but between 3.3-3.4v only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Came from another shop, so not much. Looks clean, no noticeable liquid. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is steady 12.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: <SIGNAL>G2_EN</SIGNAL> will cycle when <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> does not come high, but could be many other things. BIOS, clk chip, too. CPU Vcore coming on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is cycling high-low. I don't get CPU vcore. It's about 7 ohms to ground, doesn't seem like a short but don't have a good board to compare to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: No <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> isn't coming on all the way (less than 1v).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> doesn't seem to have anything on its gates, but <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR> does cycle to 0v on its gate.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is needed to enable <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>, check why <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is not coming high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Beat you to it :) see above.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
[QUOTE="arghhh, post: 12032"]<TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> doesn't seem to have anything on its gates, but <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR> does cycle to 0v on its gate.[/QUOTE]

This is not possible. <TRANSISTOR>Q7830</TRANSISTOR> gate can only be pulled low if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> is present which goes straight to <TRANSISTOR>Q7812</TRANSISTOR> gate.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: I know, I thought the same thing but I'm really not getting anything. It's possible that my multimeter is just too slow to pick it up, but I don't have an oscilloscope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Well, if you give me measurements that don't make sense there is nothing I can do.
